bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, July 11, 1940

div1.p: This letter contains Truby's recollections of the Yellow Fever Commission work and excerpts of his own history of the Yellow Fever Commission concerning Jesse W. Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, July 11, 1940

opener.dateline:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
July 11, 1940

div1.p:
I was deeply interested in your
letter of July 2d, for both Dr Lazear & Major Reed
were very dear friends of mine, and anything
I can do to clear up the pages of history
as to the work they did in Cuba will be a
pleasure.

Since my retirement from the Army I have
been busy gathering up my old Cuban records,
photographs, letters, official reports, etc., and
under pressure of such men as Generals
Ireland, Kean, F. F. Russell, & Reynolds, I
have been writing up the story as I saw
it. From quite extensive records, & from memory,
I have been able to take things in chronological
order, with names & dates of important events,
and who participated in them. As it is
also a story of my own experiences and
activities in Cuba, and because in telling
the facts I will have the relatives & friends
of Carroll, Agramonte, Gorgas & Finlay on
my back, I have hesitated to publish it.

I am sure you have noted that after
Reed's death, Carroll in a mild way began
to tell what he did. Then after Carroll's death
Agramonte told of the great importance of
his work, The friends of Gorgas (not Gorgas himself)
AC
T
and of Finlay tried to minimize Reed's
work and rob him of the credit for his
splendid scientific work at Camp Lazear-

I am sure you have also noted that Reed
rarely referred to anything he did personally, but
always of the Board's work. He wanted it
that way and so expressed himself in a
Baltimore address, referring especially to
Lazear- Ireland, Kean and I have often
discussed this subject and we have
always stood together in insisting that
all members of the Board should have
equal glory for their achievements as a board-
The fact remains however that Lazear
got his results with mosquitoes without
the help of anyone- Of course he was carrying
out the plans which he and Reed had worked
out, based on Carter's splendid observations
and Ross' work on Malaria- Likewise Reed
planned and did all the work at Camp Lazear
without any help from Agramonte and very
little from Carroll as he was still suffering
from the effects if his attack of yellow fever-
The two men who did more to make the Board's
work possible were General Wood & Major J. R. Kean.
Both were magnificient in their support
and constant assistance to Reed-

I am away from San Francisco, spending
a couple of weeks or more in the Santa Cruz
Mts- Consequently I have no records on
my unfinished manuscript with me- This
also accounts in the delay of your letter
3
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
which reached me yesterday- When I
return to S. F. I will have that part of my
manuscript typed which pertains to Lazear's
case of yellow fever and send it to you-

Naturally I hesitate to let someone else
publish what I have written, for much of it
is new and unknown to the public. As you
have devoted so much time and study to
the matter I am sure you would be greatly
interested in what I have written, and I think
it would jibe with information you obtained
from Kissinger & Moran. They knew what was
going on at Camp Lazear, but probably did
not know much of what went on at our
quarters. Reed's rooms and my own were
next to each other and the fine porch we had
was the general meeting place of the members
of the Board except Agramonte and the hospital staff. I was C. O.
of the hospital at that time and as such had
considerable to do in providing supplies,
equipment & personnel for Camp Lazear-

My story is quite long and it will be some
time before it is ready to be typed, Besides parts
of it are still unwritten so it could not be
published for some months- If you could
come out to California we could go over it
and discuss various matters of interest to you.
I do hope you get the essential facts
straight. Unfortunately I haven't the necessary
funds to make a trip East at this time on
I would bring it to you- Before I publish
it (if I do) I want to have Kean & a few others
go over it to get their approval or confirmation
AC
T
of any doubtful statements.

I will be very glad to have you write
me about any details and I think I can
be of some help in giving you a general
picture of what went on at Columbia Bks.
Sidney Howard in “Yellow Jack” got much of his information
from Kean, Moran & me, but while he
had many of the main facts straight, the
story was inaccurate and far from the
real picture- What a pity!

I do not know Mrs. Lazear's address.
A long time ago I heard she was living in
Los Angeles- The Surgeon General might be
able to help you find her.

I hope to be back in S. F. about the 20th of
this month, or a little later, and then will be
able to give you the story about Lazear's
infection- There wascan be no reflection on Reed
for publishing the story as he did. (On the Contrary I think it was to his Credit.) He was
convinced that Lazear's case was experimental,
but consideration for L's family made him
abide to Lazear's statement to Gorgas & Carroll-

Lazear died, as you know, a week or so
before Reed returned to Cuba and left no
information for Reed about his work, except a small note book

I hope you can make this all out
with not too much difficulty.

closer.seg:
P. S. My present address is:-
Boulder Creek
Santa Cruz Co.
Calif
